title-group.article-title: Geographical patterns of Corine land cover diversity across Europe
title-group.subtitle: The effect of grain size and thematic resolution

author-notes.corresp: Nikos Koutsias, Department of Environmental and Natural Resources Management, University of Western Greece, G. Seferi 2, Agrinio, 30100, Greece. Email: nkoutsia@cc.uoi.gr

abstract.p: Land cover diversity is often used as a surrogate of habitat heterogeneity. Nevertheless, its spatial pattern has received limited attention. Here, we examine Corine land cover diversity patterns across Europe, and test (1) if geographical (longitudinal, latitudinal) gradients exist, (2) if the scale of analysis (and specifically the grain of analysis) influences the patterns, and (3) if the thematic resolution affects the results. We estimated diversity landscape metrics for 2818 locations throughout Europe. We analysed the spatial pattern at five grains (0.25, 1, 25, 100 and 625 km2), and for three hierarchical levels of the Corine Land Cover 2000 classification scheme. To account for spatial autocorrelation, we used Clifford’s test. Latitude was significantly correlated with land cover diversity (once spatial autocorrelation was taken into account) only at large grain sizes. Longitude, with a few exceptions at fine grain, was not correlated to land cover diversity. The spatial pattern of land cover diversity is scale-dependent, with spatial pattern at fine grain (<1 km2) being statistically independent of the pattern at large grain (625 km2). Also the grain of the analysis affected the spatial autocorrelation of land cover diversity. Fine grain analysis displayed autocorrelation, but over short (hundreds of kilometres) distances, while large grain analysis displayed autocorrelation over longer distances (thousands of kilometres). Increasing the detail of the thematic resolution seems to have effects similar to increasing the grain size. The thematic resolution in certain cases influenced the results qualitatively and thus inference from low-resolution landscape analysis should be done with caution.

sec.title: I Introduction
sec.p: The spatial pattern of biodiversity has received much attention in recent decades both for applied conservation purposes (the need to designate networks of protected areas) and also because technical limitations have been lifted (wider array of computational tools and greater data sets are becoming available to scientists). As a result, the properties of biodiversity spatial pattern are becoming more apparent, as well as the gaps in our knowledge. Some already known patterns are now well established, e.g. the latitudinal gradient of biodiversity from tropics to poles (Gaston, 2007), but some interesting and unexpected quirks have also appeared. Biodiversity is not a well-behaved additive variable, thus it is documented that biodiversity spatial patterns are scale-dependent (Levin, 1992). In other words, the scale of observation affects the biodiversity spatial pattern we observe. This has been documented for taxa like birds (Hurlbert and White, 2005), invertebrates (Larrivee and Buddle, 2010) and plants (Kallimanis et al., 2008a). Also this scale-dependence has been observed in different biogeographic regions, such as temperate and Mediterranean regions, and for different scales from a few square metres to hundreds of square kilometres (Lennon et al., 2001; Lindo and Winchester, 2008).

This scale-dependence of biodiversity patterns has often been associated with different environmental factors playing a more significant role in shaping diversity at different scales (Belmaker and Jetz, 2011). Factors like climate and energy are often recognized as main drivers at coarse continental and global scales, while other factors like disturbance, productivity, topography, land cover and habitat diversity seem to be more important at intermediate scales, and still other factors like biotic interactions and micro-environmental characteristics are more important at fine scales (see, among others, Currie et al., 2004; Gillespie et al., 2008; Kallimanis et al., 2011; Kleijn et al., 2009; Kreft and Jetz, 2007).

Previous studies examining the spatial pattern of biodiversity focused, almost exclusively, on different aspects of species diversity. However, there is a line of research arguing that biodiversity is more than species diversity and it should be studied at higher hierarchical levels of organization than the species (Drakou et al., 2011; Higgins et al., 2004; Kallimanis et al., 2008b). As a matter of fact, the most often cited definition of biological diversity, which forms the basis for many conservation plans and policies, explicitly recognizes biodiversity at the ecosystem level (CBD, 1992; Gaston and Spicer, 2003; Maclaury and Sterelny, 2008). Yet today this level of biodiversity has received comparatively less research attention, and our understanding of its patterns remains fragmentary.

An important issue in landscape ecology is scale (Neel et al., 2004). Previous research documented that the scale of analysis affects the value of landscape indices including the diversity landscape indices (Baldwin et al., 2004; Hassett et al., 2012; Li and Wu, 2007; Turner et al., 1989; Wu, 2007; Wu et al., 2002). Our knowledge about how scale affects the spatial pattern of landscape indices is rather limited. Does the ranking of sites according to the diversity landscape indices change with the scale of analysis? Is the geographic location of land cover diversity hotspots and coldspots different at different scales? Stoms (1994) showed that vertebrate species richness maps in Idaho generally maintain identifiable patterns across spatial scales. However, species richness does not necessarily vary in predictable ways across scales. Other studies have shown that the spatial patterns of species diversity are scale-dependent, with the locations of the species richness hotspots and coldspots changing from one scale to another (Kallimanis et al., 2008a; Lennon et al., 2001; Shriner et al., 2006). Still researchers try to comprehend this scale-dependence in the spatial pattern of biodiversity in an attempt to describe and predict patterns in one scale from data in another (Azaele et al., 2012; BarMassada and Radelof, 2010).

In many studies of landscape ecology, land cover was classified in only few (10 or fewer) classes. In many theoretical simulation and experimental studies of connectivity and/or edge effects, landscapes are often classified in only two classes (e.g. habitat/matrix) (Graves et al., 2012; Kallimanis et al., 2002; With and Pavuk, 2011). Also, in studies based on land cover maps produced from the interpretation of remote sensing data, land cover is in most cases classified in 10 or fewer classes (Hassett et al., 2012; Leblond et al., 2011; Uriarte et al., 2011; Wickham and Norton, 1994). Even studies based on pre-existing data sets of higher thematic resolution often reclassify the data to only a few classes (De Jager and Rohweder, 2011; Desrochers et al., 2011). Previous studies documented that, at a regional extent, thematic resolution affects the value of landscape indices (Buyantuyev and Wu, 2007; Castilla et al., 2009). However, we do not know whether thematic resolution affects the spatial pattern of these indices, i.e. the geographic location of peaks and troughs of these indices.

In the present study, we used the Corine Land Cover Land Use data of Europe (European Environment Agency, 1994), where a common classification scheme has been applied consistently throughout the European Union producing comparable continent-wide land cover data. This data set allows us to analyse land cover diversity spatial patterns at continental scale. The Corine land cover classification scheme is hierarchical with three levels. The first (coarser) level has only five classes, the second level has 15 classes, and the third (finer) level has 44 classes, allowing us to examine how the thematic resolution of the classification scheme affected the patterns observed. Compared to Corine, other land cover classification schemes place greater emphasis on vegetation land cover classes (e.g. Jongman et al., 2011; Wickham and Norton, 1994). However, this does not mean that the Corine land cover classification scheme is not related to biodiversity. Previous studies have shown that even human-dominated land uses (such as cultivated land and roads) do not diminish the potential of an area to host a diverse array of habitats and species, even those of conservation priority, and may even support species not observed in natural areas (Forman and Alexander, 1998; Kallimanis et al., 2008c; Votsi et al., 2012).

Whether land cover diversity is a level of diversity that should be studied by itself or an environmental factor shaping species biodiversity patterns, it remains of ecological and conservation importance to describe and comprehend its distributional pattern. The aim of this study is to examine the spatial pattern of Corine land cover diversity at a continental scale. More specifically we tested (1) for the existence of latitudinal or longitudinal gradients in land cover diversity, (2) for the possible effects of the scale of analysis (expressed as the grain size used to measure land cover diversity) on the location of land cover diversity hotspots and coldspots, and (3) for the effect of the resolution of the classification scheme applied.

sec.title: Corine land cover 2000
sec.p: Landscape thematic content and resolution was defined at three hierarchical levels by using Corine Land Cover 2000 classes of levels I, II and III. This data set was produced in 2000 for the entire European Union and is available in vector data format. The working scale of the Corine project is 1:100,000, the smallest mapping unit is 25 ha, and it has been produced by computer-aided photo-interpretation of false-colour LANDSAT and SPOT satellite images. The unit area that has been mapped corresponds either to an area whose cover may be considered homogeneous or to a combination of elementary areas (European Environment Agency, 1994).

The physical and physiognomic land cover nomenclature of Corine comprises five categories in level I, 15 in level II (which are subdivisions of the five level I classes) and 44 in level III (which are subdivisions of the 15 level II classes). The classification scheme was identical in all European Union Member States, even if some classes were not observed in some countries. This classification scheme gives equal weight to human land use classes and natural or semi-natural land cover classes. More specifically, out of the 44 level III classes 22 are human-dominated, i.e. artificial surfaces (11 classes, including, for example, discontinuous urban fabric) and agricultural areas (11 classes, e.g. pastures) and the remaining 22 are forests and semi-natural areas (12 classes, e.g. coniferous forests), wetlands (five classes, e.g. peat bogs) and water bodies (five classes, e.g. estuaries). The full detailed nomenclature of the Corine land cover classes in the three hierarchical levels is provided in the Appendix.

sec.title: Landscape analysis and metrics
sec.p: We estimated the landscape metrics for squares of size 0.25 km2, 1 km2, 25 km2, 100 km2 and 625 km2 (25 to 62500 ha), located throughout the whole extent of the European Union. These five box sizes are the different grains used in our analysis. These minimum areas of analysis are not homogeneous and may support multiple land cover classes. To avoid creating boxes with overlapping areas that would create problems of data dependence, first we constructed a fishnet of 40 km, which covers the entire terrestrial territory of Europe with 2818 cells. Then, based on the centroid of each of these cells, randomly distributed points were created at a maximum distance of 7.5 km. Finally, boxes centred on each random point of side sizes 0.5, 1, 5, 10 and 25 km were created. To avoid issues of non-independence and to keep total number of samples constant across scales, for each grain size, we analysed a single sample from each location, i.e. we did not aggregate data from fine scale to coarse scale. Thus, for the finer scale (0.25 km2) only 0.02% of the European Union territory was covered, while for the coarser scale (625 km2) 37.7% of the European Union was covered. The use of samples of such small area and coverage of the European Union may systematically underestimate the value of the diversity landscape metrics of the European Union (Hassett et al., 2012) but it allows us to analyse the spatial pattern of land cover diversity across Europe.

We estimated the landscape metrics for the 2818 locations for the five grain sizes and for the three thematic resolutions (2818×5×3= 42270 runs) using Fragstats version 3.3. Each area analysed was converted to a raster of 30 m cell size. In the present study, we analyse land cover diversity indices (which measure how many different Corine land cover classes were observed in the study area), specifically the Shannon diversity index and Simpson diversity index (indices that take explicitly into account the coverage of each land cover class in the study area). Diversity is a complex concept that is not easily measured by a single index, therefore in the literature there is a plethora of diversity indices reflecting different aspects of diversity. The simplest and most often used is richness, which reflects the number of the different elements, placing equal weight on all elements irrespective of their contribution. However, for many applications it is important to account not only for the number of the different elements, but also for their commonness or rarity. In order to examine this facet of diversity, several indicators have been proposed, but the two most commonly used ones in landscape ecology are the Shannon and Simpson indices (Forman, 1995). Shannon’s index emphasizes the richness component of diversity, while Simpson’s index emphasizes the evenness component, i.e. it is responsive to the dominant cover type. Although they often lead to similar conclusions, it has been documented that they are not redundant and may lead to contradicting conclusions (Nagendra, 2002).

sec.title: 2 Statistical analysis
sec.p: One of the most commonly acknowledged properties of landscape patterns is spatial autocorrelation, a property that often violates the assumptions of standard statistical methods such as regression (Fortin and Dale, 2005; Gonga-Saholiariliva et al., 2011; Miller, 2012; Su et al., 2012; Wu, 2004). This has been shown also for species distributions and species diversity patterns (Kallimanis et al., 2008a; Lennon et al., 2001; Miller, 2012). To account for the effect of spatial autocorrelation, we performed correlation analysis using the modified t-test by Clifford et al. (1989). This test corrects the significance of the Pearson correlation coefficient for the spatial dependence within and between any two variables correlated. This correction uses the concept of ‘effective sample size’ (ess). This is the equivalent sample size for the two patterns when the redundancy produced by spatial autocorrelation is removed, and it is a joint property of both spatial patterns. The method analytically estimates the redundancy incorporated by the spatial autocorrelation and corrects the sample size and hence the degrees of freedom for the statistical significance measurement, without discarding data. Since we were interested in the spatial pattern of land cover diversity across Europe and detecting the geographical (latitudinal or longitudinal) gradients, only short-distance autocorrelation was taken into account (by truncating the correlogram). This analysis was performed with SAM (Rangel et al., 2010).

To analyse the spatial pattern, we used semivariograms, a geostatistical technique that graphically presents both the intensity and scale of the spatial pattern of quantitative variables. Semivariograms plot the mean variance of cells that are a given distance apart against this distance, thus showing how the variance of the quantitative variable changes with distance (Fortin and Dale, 2005). The semivariograms were estimated using SAM (Rangel et al., 2010).

sec.title: 1 Latitudinal/longitudinal gradients
sec.p: When we tested for latitudinal or longitudinal gradients in land cover diversity, we found that, once short distance spatial autocorrelation was taken into account, few correlations were significant. According to the modified Clifford test, as scale becomes coarser (the grain size of the analysis becomes larger) the relationship between land cover diversity and latitude becomes stronger and it changes direction (Table 1). While at fine grain of analysis the relationship is positive, but not significant, at large grain sizes the relationship is negative and significant. Also, as the Corine classification scheme becomes more detailed (higher level), the relationship becomes stronger. The observed patterns were similar for all diversity indices analysed (land cover richness, Shannon diversity index, Simpson diversity index). Longitude, on the other hand, plays a less important role, and almost no correlation was significant. The only two exceptions were observed for the smallest grain size and level III of Corine (Table 1).

caption.p: Correlations between land cover diversity and latitude or longitude. Land cover diversity has been measured either as land cover class richness, or with the use of Shannon and Simpson diversity indices. For this calculation, the three hierarchical levels of the Corine land cover land use classification scheme have been used. Also, the analysis was performed at five different scales (from 0.25 up to 625 km2). For the correlation analysis, spatial autocorrelation has been taken into consideration using the Clifford test. So for each correlation we present the Pearson correlation coefficient (R), the statistical significance (p) and the corrected degrees of freedom, i.e. the effective sample size (ess), which represents how large the sample size would have been if there was no autocorrelation.

sec.title: 2 Effects of grain size
sec.p: The previous analysis highlights the role of scale (expressed as the grain of analysis) as a differentiating factor in the observed patterns. Therefore, we compared the spatial patterns of land cover diversity across the grains of our study. The scale of analysis (i.e. the grain size) significantly affects the value of the land cover diversity indices. The distribution of values of land cover richness shifts to higher values as the grain size increases in all thematic resolutions (Figure 1). At level III of the Corine classification scheme (with 44 classes), the average richness increased from 2.04 (at grain size 0.25 km2) to 15.08 (at grain size 625 km2), the maximum observed richness increased from 6 to 32, and the median increased from 2 to 15 (Figure 1A). At the least informative thematic resolution (Corine hierarchical level I with five classes), the average richness values increased from 1.48 (at grain size 0.25 km2) to 4.24 (at grain size 625 km2), while the median increased from 1 to 4 (Figure 1C). A similar pattern is observed with the Shannon and Simpson diversity indices. At Corine level III average Shannon diversity index increased with increasing grain size from 0.410 to 1.628, while at Corine level I it increased from 0.202 to 0.705. Similarly at Corine level III the average Simpson index increased with increasing grain size from 0.256 to 0.697, while at Corine level I it increased from 0.131 to 0.404.

caption.p: Distribution of values of land cover richness at different scales of analysis. The squares represent the median value, the boxes represent the 75% interval and the whiskers represent the 95% interval. The distribution has been estimated for all thematic resolution of the Corine land cover classification from the finest level III with 44 classes (A), the intermediate level II with 15 classes (B) and the coarsest level I with five classes (C).

sec.p: As far as the spatial pattern of land cover class richness is concerned, it appears that for small changes in the grain of the analysis the spatial patterns of land cover diversity remain significantly correlated (Table 2). But for large changes in the grain of the analysis (more than 25 times), the two spatial patterns are not significantly correlated. Furthermore, as the difference in grain of analysis becomes greater the correlation coefficient becomes smaller, so even when the relationship persists it explains only a small percentage of the variation. The peaks and troughs of land cover diversity are located in different parts of Europe at different grain sizes (Figure 2). For example, Sicily appears as a diversity coldspot at fine scales (small grain size), and as a diversity hotspot at coarse scale (large grain sizes) for all levels of classification. As far as the Shannon and Simpson diversity indices are concerned, the spatial patterns of land cover diversity in most cases remained correlated, but the strength of the relationship deteriorated as the difference in grain size increased. Even more clearly in the Corine classification level I, the spatial patterns at one grain (625 km2) are not significantly correlated to the patterns at other grains.

caption.p: The spatial pattern of land cover diversity across Europe. Land cover diversity is measured as richness of land cover classes. Lighter colours represent low diversity values, while darker colours represent higher diversity values. Each row represents a different level of the Corine land cover classification scheme (Level I with five classes, level II with 15 classes, and level III with 44 classes), while each column represents a different grain size (the three grain sizes presented are 0.25, 100 and 625 km2). Correlations between land cover diversity spatial pattern from one scale to another (all pairwise comparisons among the five scales of analysis). Land cover diversity has been measured as land cover class richness, as Shannon diversity index and as Simpson diversity index. The analysis was repeated for the three hierarchical levels of the Corine land cover land use classification scheme. For the correlation analysis, spatial autocorrelation has been taken into consideration using the Clifford test. So for each correlation we present the correlation Pearson coefficient (R), the statistical significance (p) and the effective sample size (ess).

sec.title: 3 Effects of thematic resolution
sec.p: The results of Figure 1 and Tables 1 and 2 show that thematic resolution affected the outcome of the analysis, so we compared the spatial pattern of diversity as calculated from different Corine classification levels. For a given grain size the value of the landscape index depends on the thematic resolution with less detailed classification schemes scoring lower values than more detailed ones (Figure 1). The spatial patterns were significantly correlated among levels, with the exception of the comparison between level I and level II or level III at the coarsest scale (largest grain size) (Table 3). The comparisons among levels II and III were always significant and strong (correlation coefficient for all but two comparisons greater than 0.698). The comparison between levels II and I was less strong (correlation coefficient did not exceed 0.752). The comparison between levels III and I was even weaker (correlation coefficient did not exceed 0.63). Also, in every pairwise comparison, as the spatial scale of the analysis became coarser (the grain size became larger) the strength of the correlation decreased. Nordic countries score the highest diversity values at the level I of Corine, but score the comparatively low values at level III (this is even more apparent at the coarsest spatial scale of the third column of Figure 2).

caption.p: Correlations between land cover diversity as estimated by the three hierarchical levels of the Corine land cover classification scheme. Land cover diversity has been measured as land cover class richness, as Shannon diversity index and as Simpson diversity index. The analysis was repeated at all spatial scales (0.25, 1, 25, 100 and 625 km2). For the correlation analysis, spatial autocorrelation has been taken into consideration using the Clifford test. So for each correlation we present the Pearson correlation coefficient (R), the statistical significance (p) and the effective sample size (ess).

sec.title: 4 Spatial autocorrelation patterns
sec.p: Finally, we analysed the spatial autocorrelation of the patterns using the semivariograms. The semivariograms show that all patterns have short distance autocorrelation, but the sill is reached at different distances for the different grains of the analysis (Figure 3). At finer grains the sill is reached at relatively short distances, while at coarser grains this is achieved at longer distances, indicating that the spatial pattern of land cover diversity remains correlated for longer distances. These trends were observed for all diversity indices analysed.

caption.p: Semivariograms representing the spatial autocorrelation pattern of land cover diversity across Europe. Land cover diversity is measured as richness of land cover classes at different grain sizes (0.25, 1, 25, 100 and 625 km2). For comparative purposes, the semivariance at each grain size has been standardized to its maximum value (i.e. by 1.538 for grain size 0.25 km2, by 3.052 for 1 km2, by 15.11 for 25 km2, by 27.39 for 100 km2 and by 78.32 for 625 km2). (See colour version of this figure online).

sec.title: 1 Latitudinal/longitudinal gradients
sec.p: First, we tried to elucidate the spatial patterns of land cover diversity at continental scale by testing for the existence of geographical gradients. We found that, even when spatial autocorrelation was taken into consideration, latitude was significantly correlated to land cover diversity only at coarse spatial scales (grain size larger than 25 km2). Also it seems that as the scale of analysis became coarser, and as the thematic resolution of the classification scheme became more detailed, the strength of the relationship between latitude and land cover diversity increased. This pattern is in accordance with the well-established latitudinal gradient observed in species diversity (Gaston, 2007, and references therein). Longitude, on the other hand, seems to play a less significant role, since it was not significantly correlated to land cover diversity. Wickham et al. (1995) found the opposite pattern when examining vegetation diversity across the USA at coarse scales (grain size 500 mi2 or greater), with vegetation diversity increasing from east to west, but not correlated to latitude. This discrepancy might be due to the fact that they analysed only vegetation diversity and did not include other land cover classes, or it might imply that these patterns are influenced by biogeographical factors, and should not be considered universal.

sec.title: 2 Effects of grain size
sec.p: This analysis highlighted the role of scale for the spatial patterns observed. Previous studies have provided ample documentation that the scale of analysis affects the value of landscape metrics including land cover diversity metrics (Baldwin et al., 2004; Jelinski and Wu, 1996; Li and Wu, 2007; Turner et al., 1989; Wu, 2004). Here, we also showed that as the grain of analysis increased so did the value of all diversity indices calculated. Wickham et al. (1995) showed how vegetation richness relationship to topographical characteristics is scale-dependent. But the spatial pattern of the values of the landscape metrics, i.e. the geographical locations of vegetation richness hotspots and coldspots, was not examined explicitly. We found that the spatial pattern of land cover diversity was scale-dependent. More specifically, we found that the geographic location of the peaks and troughs of land cover class richness at the fine scale (grain size 0.25 km2) did not coincide with those at the coarse scale (grain size 625 km2).

There are also important ecological implications of this scale-dependency in diversity patterns. Today there is ample documentation that the spatial pattern of biodiversity is scale-dependent (see, among others, Hurlbert and White, 2005; Kallimanis et al., 2008a; Lennon et al., 2001). The majority of the relevant literature argues that this is the outcome of different environmental factors being more important drivers for biodiversity at different scales of observation (see Belmaker and Jetz, 2011; Kallimanis et al., 2006, 2008b; Rahbek and Graves, 2001). Here we showed that the spatial pattern of land cover diversity is scale-dependent. One cannot help speculate if the apparent scale-dependency of species diversity might be inherited by the underlying scale-dependence of land cover diversity, and thus be the result of a single factor (landscape diversity) across scales, rather than different factors at each scale. In other words, what if species diversity patterns are consistently correlated to landscape diversity patterns, which are scale-dependent and which are correlated to different environmental factors at different scales? This is only speculation and should be read with caution since it is not tested. The empirical testing of such a hypothesis is beyond the scope of the present study.

Previous studies have considered landscape indices calculated from Corine land cover to perform poorly as indicators of plant diversity (Gimona et al., 2009) or insect diversity (Carre et al., 2009). Yet, given the scale-dependency of both species diversity patterns and land cover diversity patterns, there is the possibility that the poor performance was the result of scale mismatch rather than lack of relationship.

The scale-dependence of the land cover diversity pattern seems to be related to the existence of a few rare land cover classes, such as road and rail networks (Corine code 122) which always cover only a small surface area but directly affect landscape composition and diversity (Forman and Alexander, 1998; Votsi et al., 2012). Once the relative abundance of the different elements of the landscape is taken into consideration (e.g. by using Shannon’s or Simpson’s diversity index), then the spatial pattern mismatch across the scales examined in the present study becomes weaker. So a mechanism for explaining the scale-dependence of land cover diversity might reflect that at fine scales there is limited space, and given the mapping detail of Corine only a few land cover classes could be present. As larger areas are examined, more land covers could be observed (and especially rare land cover classes that occupy small patches in the landscape), thus increasing land cover richness, but without changing the dominance patterns. Moreover, this finding highlights the importance of the spatial turnover of land cover classes in defining overall land cover diversity. But this is part of the answer because as the grain of analysis becomes larger it is not only the geographic location of the land cover coldspots and hotspots that is affected, but also the spatial autocorrelation properties. At fine grain sizes the value of land cover diversity index is spatially autocorrelated only over short distances (hundreds of kilometres), while at large grain sizes the spatial autocorrelation remains over longer distances (thousands of kilometres).

sec.title: 3 Effects of thematic resolution
sec.p: An important issue in measuring land cover diversity is the land cover classification scheme. So far, several such schemes have been proposed (e.g. FAO land cover classes, Habitat’s directive Annex 1 habitat classes, General Habitat Categories). A possible limitation of the Corine scheme is that it gives more weight to human land use classes than any alternative scheme. A more detailed classification scheme with more information on vegetation might bring forward more ecological insights. This caveat might imply that land cover diversity is not identical to ecosystem or habitat diversity, and thus may not be the most appropriate tool for nature conservation. However, the relationship between land cover diversity and biodiversity (at ecosystem, habitat or species level) remains an open research question.

On the other hand, this is the only one landscape classification scheme applied throughout the European Union and for which continental wide data on land cover are available. However, there are certain uncertainties built into the methodology of defining Corine land cover classes, especially regarding the agricultural areas at level III, which might be interpreted differently in different countries. For example, in a landscape mosaic of agricultural area, some countries may identify the entire region as ‘Complex cultivation patterns’ (Corine code 242) or as ‘Land principally occupied by agriculture, with significant areas of natural vegetation’ (Corine code 243), while other countries might map each mosaic element separately producing a more detailed map. This discrepancy might lead to different estimations for the number of classes, at least at Level III, in different European countries, e.g. north versus south.

Many landscape ecology studies are based on landscape being classified in fewer than 10 land cover classes. The effect of the thematic resolution on the observed patterns has received limited attention. Buyantuyev and Wu (2007) documented that thematic resolution may significantly affect the value of landscape indices (including diversity indices) and also the ability to detect landscape changes. Bailey et al. (2007) also documented how thematic resolution affected the value of landscape indices and their relationship to the diversity of different taxa. Thematic resolution determines the amount of detail used in the analysis, and changing thematic resolution changed the values of all land cover diversity indices calculated, as was reported by Buyantuyev and Wu (2007), Saura (2004) and Wu (2004).

We examined not only how the average value of diversity indices is affected but also the spatial pattern of these indices at continental scale. Baldwin et al. (2004) discussed how the sensitivity of landscape indices to thematic resolution varies spatially. The comparison among the three Corine hierarchical levels seems to work in a way similar to the higher taxon surrogacy observed in species diversity patterns (Mazaris et al., 2008, 2010). The spatial patterns remain, in almost all cases, significantly correlated, indicating that even coarse classification of major land cover classes conveys a significant portion of the information. But the strength of the correlation decreases as the scale of analysis coarsens (at the coarsest scale the spatial pattern of level I classification was statistically independent from the pattern of the other two levels) and as the difference in resolution increases (for any index the comparison among levels III and I was the weakest). At fine spatial scales (small grain size) the use of the less detailed classification schemes for the estimation of land cover diversity spatial patterns works satisfactorily as a surrogate for more detailed thematic resolutions, since the results of the analysis may differ quantitatively but not qualitatively. However, at coarse spatial scales (large grain size) this is not necessarily true. We should point out that the choice of scale should take into account the research question, organism/process under consideration and the purpose of the study.

Changing the grain of the analysis and changing the thematic resolution seem to operate in a similar way (in accordance with the findings of Baldwin et al., 2004; Buyantuyev and Wu, 2007; Saura, 2004). As grain becomes coarser or as thematic resolution becomes more detailed, the value of the diversity landscape metrics increases. For large differences, even the spatial pattern properties change, and more importantly the geographic location of diversity peaks and troughs change.
